qas.question: What type of animal belonging to Queen Elizabeth II was killed by an intruding fox on the Buckingham Palace grounds?
What animal was seen sleeping in London's Parliament Building?
Approximately how many foxes live in the City of London?
In 2001, what organization conducted a survey of residents regarding London's fox population?
What is London's fox population density?

answers.text: 16 foxes for every square mile (2.6 square kilometres)

context: Among other inhabitants of London are <a2_0>10,000<a2_0/> <a1_0>fox<a1_0/>es, so that there are now <a4_0>16 foxes for every square mile (2.6 square kilometres)<a4_0/> of London. These urban foxes are noticeably bolder than their country cousins, sharing the pavement with pedestrians and raising cubs in people's backyards. Foxes have even sneaked into the Houses of Parliament, where one was found asleep on a filing cabinet. Another broke into the grounds of Buckingham Palace, reportedly killing some of Queen Elizabeth II's prized <a0_0>pink flamingos<a0_0/>. Generally, however, foxes and city folk appear to get along. A survey in 2001 by <a3_0>the London-based Mammal Society<a3_0/> found that 80 percent of 3,779 respondents who volunteered to keep a diary of garden mammal visits liked having them around. This sample cannot be taken to represent Londoners as a whole.
